VOL. LXII, NO. 23

S. C. Vote Prostitutes

An unknown thief calmly entered an unlocked room
in the new dormitories last Friday night and made off
with between $500 and $600 in small bills and change
which had been stored in a student's foot locker.
John Makin, a junior class student living on the first
floor of Hollander House, reported the robbery after discovering the cash missing last Saturday afternoon. He explained to investigating police that the money had been
derived from concessions at Hopkins' first two lacrosse
games.

Voting on a motion by Joel
Woodey of the Honor Commission, the Council voted 8 to 6 to
include the News-Letter and unanimously to include the Cotillion Board.

Cotillion Board
Elects Saner
As President
Bill Sauer has been selected
President of the Cotillion Board
at this week's Board elections.
Besides Sauer, the new officers
are: Business Mauager, Dick
Einaugler; Assistant Business
Manager, Boland McCamy, and
Secretary, Joseph Dickerman.

The News-Letter and the Cotillion Board will now be represented on the Student Council,
as the result of motions passed
at this week's meeting of the
Council.

Final approval will have to be
given by the student body, in the
form of a referendum. Council
members said that the motion
would be presented to the students probably at the same time
as the freshman elections, scheduled td be run off in several
weeks.
ODK Excluded
In action taken on another
motion proposed by Woodey,
Which would have included the
President of Omicron Delta Kappa on the Council, members of
the Council voted overwhelmingly to exclude this organization.
The consensus of opinion seemed
to be that ODK was already represented unofficially by many
Council members.

Bare Knees, Leis
To Spark Dance
Tomorrow Night
The Bermuda Ball, scheduled
for Saturday, April 19, from 9
until 1 in the gym, is expected
to be a great success, according
to Veteran's Club President Mac
Johnson.
Music will be furnished by the
Debonaires, and there will be an
abundance of favors—both leis
and Bermuda Ball hats.
The
decorations will be in keeping
with the informal atmosphere of
the dance and in general will be
similar to those of last year.
Also featured at this year's
dance will be round tables instead of the conventional rectangular ones. The concessions
will be run by the Vet's Club, and
set-ups will be provided at a
nominal price. The coat check
service will be handled by Alpha
Phi Omega.
" Tickets may be purchased
through Friday for $2.25 from
any member of the Vet's Club,
in the Vet's Club office from 8 to
4 and in Levering Cafeteria and
the dormitory dining hall during
lunch time. Tickets purchased
at the door Saturday night will
cost $2.50.
About 400 couples are expected,
and Johnson emphasized the
importance of a large turnout
since the Vet's Club is considering erecting World War II and
Korean War monuments on campus. The proceeds from this
dance could be used to start a
monument fund.

Out-going President Warren
Wilhide
expressed confidence
that the new Board would have
a successful year. "I think the
Board made good selections for
officers," he commented. Beginning at the next Cotillion Board
meeting the newly - admitted
freshman representatives will
become official Board members,
Wilhide explained.
When asked about his plans
for the coming year, PresidentElect Sauer explained that the
Board is working on the new
BIA-Cotillion Board Calendar,
and that "we will inform all
heads of organizations about
their dates in order to remind
them to start planning early and
avoid having to switch dates."
Commenting on the recent
Student Council move to admit
the Cotillion Board President as
one of its members, Sauer said,
"I feel it is an improvement
for both organizations since 1
have thought for some time all
campus leaders should be admitted to give the Council a
better knowledge of campus
activities. This action will give
the Council more ideas and experience."

Detectives ascertained that the
thief or thieves must have entered the room between 8:1510 p.m. Friday while its occupants were out, Makin explained
that the door and windows of
the room were unlocked but that
the foot locker under his bed
was locked. The thief ripped the
hinge screws out of the wood,
apparently with a screwdriver,
and removed the money, leaving the lock untouched.
"The thief tampered with
nothing else in the room," Makin.
added.
Lynn Rogers, director of the
Hopkins Placement Bureau
which is in charge of student
employment, explained that the
missing money included merchandise costs and salaries for
the student-run
concessions.
Frank Porter and Makin are co.
managers of the concessions,
which employ students to sell
light refreshments at home
athletic events.
"The thief may or may not
have been a student, but whoever it was he was familiar with
the layout," commented Rogers.
Makin explained that he and
his roommate had gone to the
Junior Prom Friday night and
that he did not discover the theft
until early Saturday afternoon
when he opened the locker to deposit money from the Prom.
Makin was chairman of Friday
night's dance.
"The police came immediately
and made a thorough investigation. They took pictures and
made finger-prints," Makin said,
adding that "the money wasn't
my own, but I hope it is recovered."
"It evidently was' a student or
someone extremely familiar with
the layout of dormitory rooms,"
Makin stated.
Police and detectives are making a complete investigation, but
made no reports of any progress
made this week.

Decker Urges IFB
To Induct Prexies
FLASH — Steve Broening of
Beta was elected president and
Pete Doyle of Phi Psi, vicepresident, at yesterday's special
Inter-Fraternity Board election.
A secretary was elected at today's regular IFB meeting.
IFB President Gil Decker presented an annual report to the
Student Council this week in
which he strongly urged that
fraternity presidents be made
members of the Board.
Attacking what he called the
"sometimes poor quality of the
representatives," Decker said,
"often the case is that a fraternity sends a man to the Board
for one of two reasons. It may
not want to give him any other
job and thus appoint him as a
representative to the IFB to get
rid of him. Or it may appoint

an underclassman who is popular
so that he may be in line for a
possible presidency or vice-presidency."
He added, "We never got
around to discussing this problem this year due to the problem of changing the rush rules,
but I would like very much for
next year's IFB to discuss this
as quickly 'as possible."
Break Even
outlined
Decker
the
also
financial position of the Board,
saying it spent some $300 extra
for the fall dance. He added
that the IFB should be able "to
break even if it keeps to our
budget this term."
He testified the IFB has spent
over three months attempting to
modify t h e existing rush
rules. He stated that a committee had first suggested a prom

with the usually scheduled fall
dances, he answered that it
might, but this problem was not
up to the IFB to solve but up to
the sponsoring organizations.
"It's purely a business matter.
These groups know that they
can make more money if they
hold their dances during the
rush period."
Decker also said that the vigilance duty of the IFB had been
"very lax" this year, but added,
"I have had occasion to talk to
Dean Shaffer several times this
year and he has been pleased

Albert D. Hutzler has been appointed chairman of the Cornmitee for New Buildings to be
constructed at the Homewood
campus.
D. Luke Hopkins, chairman of
the Johns Hopkins Fund, which
is handling Hopkins' drive to
raise $76,000,000 in the next ten
years, also announced that
Charles S. Garland will head a
special committee to direct
solicitations from philotherapic
foundations.
Hutzler's Activities
Mr. Hutzler is a 1908 Hopkins
graduate. He has been Chairman of the Board of Hutzler
Brothers company since 1954. He
is a Trustee of the University,
has been an officer of the
Friends of the Library since its
formation in 1931 and has been
active in Baltimore civic affairs

Hopkins Scholar
Receives Grant
Dr. Joseph D. H. Donnay, professor of crystalography and
mineralogy at Johns Hopkins,
has been awarded a Fulbright
Grant to enable him to lecture
at the University of Paris next
year.
A native of Belgium, Dr. Donnay has held his present position at Hopkins since 1946. He
attended the University of Liege.
Belgium, and received his Ph.D.
degree from Stanford University in 1929.
He has written widely on the
fields of crystalography and mineralogy, included a book entitled
Crystal Data.

for many years.
Two buildings at Hopkins are
among the four priority projects
in the $76,000,000 program. They
are a library, estimated to cost
$4,000,000, and a physics building, estimated at $2,500,000. '
Mr. Hutzler said the need for
both buildings is critical. "During the past sixteen years, the
number of books in the library
has more than doubled, and the
library facilities in Gilman Hall,
which were designed to accommodate 200,000 volumes, now
contain 700,000."
Size Factor
Committee
Buildings
The
chairman added that the size of
the physics faculty and the
number of graduate students has
quadrupled since the present
physics building, Rowland Hall,
was built in 1929.
"A dequate facilities are
needed," Mr Hutzler said, "to
house the many new and heavy
types of instruments and machines which are today such a
fundamental part of the study of
physics and nucleonics."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL. 18, 1958

Guidance Association Gets
Gov't. Official For Speech
Applications are now being accepted for the annual spring
meeting of the Maryland Personnel and Guidance Association
to be held on April 26 at The
Johns Hopkins University.
The meeting is open to counselors in elementary and secondary schools, colleges and universities, and to personnel administrators in business, industry, and governmental agencies.
Acting as host for the conference will be the Department of
Education at Johns Hopkins.
About 300 persons are expected
to attend the meetings.
O'Connell To Speak
Highlighting the morning session will be a speech by The
Honorable James T. O'Connell,
Under Secretary of Labor.
In the afternoon the conference attendees will discuss seven
areas of interest: guidance work
in the junior college, counselor certification, job analysis
of the counselor, problems of

seling and their implications for
the practicing counselor.

Parents' Day To Feature
Banquet, Play, Lacrosse
Annual Parents' Day at the
Homewood will be held this year
on Saturday, April 26. The
parents of all Hopkins students
have received invitations to attend, and with the cooperation
of the participating hosts, the
day should prove to he an informative one for all present.
Joe Jeziorski, chairman of the
Student Council committee for
Parents' Day, was quoted as saying that "it certainly isn't too
late for parents to make reservations for Parents' Day. They're
$3.25 per person." Reservations
may be made through Jeziorski
by dropping a note in box_ 1128.
Tour Of Campus
Plans call for the day to begin at Levering Hall at ten
o'clock with a coffee hour and a
short briefing on what else will
be taking place, where, and
when. At 10:30 ODK will take
over by conducting a number of
Parents through the labs, buildings, classes and various other

Orientation
Anyone interested in serving on Orientation Week committees should turn in their
name, class, previous experience, major and box number to Charles Ginsberg, Box
2024. The deadline is Tuesday, April 22.

interesting spots on campus. At
approximately 11:30 everyone
will again meet, this time at
Shriver Hall, where Dr. Clarence
Long will address the group on
the topic of the Hopkins role in
education from the viewpoint of
a professor in a certain field.
The group will then disband to
eat lunch, parents and students
to secure their own. A section
will be reserved in the stands
for all guests for the HopkinsLoyola lacrosse game.
Banquet Follows Lacrosse
The evening's program will
commence at 6:30 with a
banquet at Levering Hall. Professor Thomas Hubbard will be
the master of ceremonies; Dean
Schaffer will give the main
speech, the keynote again being
education. Following the banquet, the "Y" will play host with
a program and awards. A number of the faculty -will be at the
tables with the parents.
This is as far as the present
plans go, but the parents may
want to attend the Barnstormer's production of "Charlie's
Aunt." A number of fraternities
are considering holding open
house for the parents of their
members.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 18, 1958

Dr. Fagin, Soon To Leave,
Speaks On O'Neill Critics
By PAUL BERMAN
This year's final Amos Taylor,
Jr. Memorial Lecture was delivered last Sunday evening in the
balcony foyer of Shriver Hall.
The lecturer, Dr. N. Bryllion
Fagin, retired professor of drama
and English at this university.
chose for his topic, "Eugene
O'Neill and his Critics." As with
his forthcoming book on this
topic, Dr. Fagin's lecture concerned itself with the career of
New London, Connecticut born
playwright Eugene O'Neill, and
his critics.
In his opening remarks, Dr.
Fagin acknowledged the fact
that he was dealing with a very
controversial figure in the person of O'Neill. Eugene O'Neill's
plays have been reviewed and
criticized in many parts of the
world. They have been performed
in Germany, Japan and Sweden.
Playgoers in the latter country
have been particularly receptive
to the works of O'Neill. His
somewhat autobiographical play,
"Long Day's Journey into Night,"
received its world premiere by
the Royal Swedish Theatre in
1956.
Consistent with human nature,
the more honors O'Neill received
for his playwrighting, the more
unfavorable his critics became.
When he received the Nobel
Prize in 1936, criticism was at
its height.
Expelled Princetonian
Eugene O'Neill was a modest
man who began his literary career as a poet. Although O'Neill
had attended the best schools

In 1914, it was discovered that
O'Neill had consumption. While
in a New London, Connecticut,
saniforium, he had plenty of
time to think. He translated his
thoughts into several small oneact playlets about the sea. Upon

of his manuscripts to a little
theatre group, "The Provincetown Players." This group produced these playlets with great
success. Eventually, "Provincetown Players" presented O'Neill's
first full-length play, Beyond
the Horizon, on Broadway in
1921. This play received rave reviews and was followed in succeeding years by The Emperor
Jones and The Hairy Ape.
O'Neill discarded proven playwrighting formulae and adopted
new styles over the years (including one, two, and even nineact plays.)

A Prior Restraint
The Student Council, by voting to include a representative of this paper in its membership, has attempted,
regardless of the good intention of some of its representatives, to pull a cutie known as 'ham stringing'. It has
turned a deaf ear upon our written and verbal arguments
against membership, and thus, we feel, committed an open
flagrancy known in law circles as 'prior restraint': knowing that this column has often criticized the actions of
the Council, and realizing that this column might be
hesitant to do so if it is included in Council membership,
the Council enacted legislation countering our action prior
to the enactment of any such action.
A referendum is in the offing. Our arguments are
in the news story on page 1. We ask that the undergraduates vote wisely on that referendum.
We trust that if we become a Student Council member
our successors, regardless of popular sentiment regarding
the reasoning behind a blast, will continue to criticize the
Council if they feel justified to do so. However, we editors
would not like to put them on the spot, and therefore ask
that the referendum not be passed.
What will happen if our successors refuse to attend
meetings? The Student Council has the power to dissolve
the News-Letter, we were informed. That we'd like to see.

Correspondence
(By the Author of"Rally Round the Flag,Boys!"and,

THE POSTMAN COMETH
I

have recently received several letters from readers which
have been so interesting, so piquant, so je ne sais quoi, that I
feel I must share them with all of you. The letters and my
replies follow:
SIR:
Maybe you can help me. I came up to college eight years
ago. On my very first day I got into a bridge game in the
student union. I am still in the same bridge game. I have never
gone to class, cracked a book, or paid any tuition. All I do
is play bridge.
To explain my long absence and keep the money coining
from home, I told a harmless little lie; I said I was in medical
school. This made Dad (my father) terribly proud. It also
enabled me to keep playing bridge. We were both very happy.
But all good things must come to an end. Mine ended when
I came home for Christmas vacation. I arrived to find that
Sister (my sister) was in the hospital with an ingrown spleen.
Dr. Norbert Sigafoos, the eminent ingrown spleen surgeon, was
scheduled to operate, but unfortunately he was run over by
a hot-food cart on the way to the scrubbing room.

(Continued from Page 6)
the life of the students in the
dormitories.
In this time and in this country, in a city that has received
praise for its courage in simply
allowing children with two types
of skin pigmentation to attend
school together, the fact remains
that Hopkins is truly an island
of freedom and, equality in a
wide, tragic sea; and that we are
still isolated, still sealed off from
the people of this city.
John M. Brewer
To the Editors:
When I first came to Hopkins
over three years ago I was'forced
by social pressure to learn an
interminable card game called
Pinochle. As if this weren't
enough, I now have been forced
to learn a new, equally interminable and even more frustrating game called bridge. I have
been forced to sit through hours
of .pure misery, enduring the
silent scorn that only superior
bridge-players can bestow upon
the neophyte.
However, the purpose behind
this letter is not to complain of
the lack of sympathy accorded
my mistakes. I have noticed
the sudden superabundance of
bridge games extending until
very late in the evening or early
in the morning. When these
take place in the Snack Bar,

I have noticed that Mary is often
prevented from being able to
close up as early as she would
like. Then too, the noise and
rather foul language must greatly try her patience.
While it is too much to be
expected that the bridge games
will cease or at least be confined
to more reasonable hours of the
evening, I would like to suggest
that the DSRC use some of the
vast amount of space available
in the basement to set up a card
room. A few tables and solidlyconstructed chairs could be provided, good lighting installed,
and a deep pit sunk in the floor
for cigarette butts, candy wrappers, and unsuccessful players
who go down, doubled and vulnerable, on one bids.
I suggest this instead of the
dormitory lounges, which are
poorly lighted and cannot generally furnish a sufficiency of
chairs for the players.
I might add, also, that the
late, late shift of cardsmen invariably manages to completely
litter the area which they

Berg Outlines Plans
In outlining his plans for the
coming year, Berg said; "We
have something to offer which
no other AM radio station in
Baltimore can boast of—a vast
library of classical music. We
will broadcast about seven hours
of this music a day."
Berg explained that W,THIJ
has extended its air time from
the former 36 hours to 87 hours
a week, and that this has been
made possible "partly due to an
arrangement I made with WITH
FM to broadcast their programs
over AM." He said that WJHU
now broadcasts WITH-FM from
3-6 p.m. daily, from 10 a.m. to
midnight Saturda'y, and from
10. a.m.-6 p.m. Sunday.
Calibre To Improve
"The calibre of our own programs will improve immediately," Berg stated, adding that "we
now run from 3 p.m. to 3 a.m. on
weekdays, with a special show of
humor and jazz called 'Lucifer'
occupying the midnight to 3
slot."
Regarding several new technical improvements, Berg explained that WJHU is experimenting with new methods
of full fidelity broadcasting
"that will soon enable our listeners to hear WJHU as well as anY
commercial station."

By STAN HANDMAKER
Sports Editor
Wins by the varsity baseball, lacrosse, and tennis
teams last week give the Hopkins spring sports perspective
a bright outlook for this year.
The baseball team gained an upset victory over Loyola,
7-2, at the Greyhounds' home field last Tuesday. The netinen also pulled an upset, downing the Randolph-Macon
Yellow Jackets, 5-3, last Saturday at Ashland, Virginia,
While the stickmen won as expected, 16-7, over Princeton
at the Tigers' home .grounds.
Following the Jays' win on the diamond over Harvard,
Paul Menton, sports editor of the Baltimore Sun, mentioned
the game in a list under the title "The Impossible Can
Happen" We would like to call to Mr. Menton's attention
'Hopkins' win over Loyola, demonstrating that the "impossible" can happen more than once with the same team.
As to the tennis squad's league victory over RandolphMacon, we are glad to see that the "minor" sports are
.iving more-than-minor performances. Hopkins is cur12e.ntly in first- place in the northern league of the Mason'Dixon conference.
The lacrosse team is expected to continue its winning
Ways, meeting Washington and Lee this Saturday at 2:30
Pan. on Homewood Field. The Generals' goalie, who gave
Lhe best performance against the Blue Jays last year,
,
tu,eing credited with twenty-nine saves, poses the greatest
threat. However, Hopkins still has what we consider the
attack to compensate for Lewis's or any other goalie's
capability in the nets.
Although we realize that the Jays have to play each
gaine as it comes, we are looking to the last three games,
(Navy, Maryland, and Mt. Washington) for Hopkins to
show its true colors.
The big. question these days is "If Army and Hopkins
('0th finish their seasons undefeated, who wins the chamPionship ?"
Ross Smith, president of the United' States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, stated in the Sun that the
,championship will not be decided on strict points and that
both schedules will have to be evaluated.

VOL. LXII, NO. 23

S. C. Vote Prostitutes
Cotillion Board,N-L

An unknown thief calmly entered an unlocked room
in the new dormitories last Friday night and made off
with between $500 and $600 in small bills and change
which had been stored in a student's foot locker.
John Makin, a junior class student living on the first
floor of Hollander House, reported the robbery after discovering the cash missing last Saturday afternoon. He explained to investigating police that the money had been
derived from concessions at Hopkins' first two lacrosse
games.

Voting on a motion by Joel
Woodey of the Honor Commission, the Council voted 8 to 6 to
include the News-Letter and unanimously to include the Cotillion Board.

at this week's Board elections.
Besides Sauer, the new officers
are: Business Mauager, Dick
Einaugler; Assistant Business
Manager, Boland McCamy, and
Secretary, Joseph Dickerman.

The News-Letter and the Cotillion Board will now be represented on the Student Council,
as the result of motions passed
at this week's meeting of the
Council.

Final approval will have to be
given by the student body, in the
form of a referendum. Council
members said that the motion
would be presented to the students probably at the same time
as the freshman elections, scheduled td be run off in several
weeks.
ODK Excluded
In action taken on another
motion proposed by Woodey,
Which would have included the
President of Omicron Delta Kappa on the Council, members of
the Council voted overwhelmingly to exclude this organization.
The consensus of opinion seemed
to be that ODK was already represented unofficially by many
Council members.

Bare Knees, Leis
To Spark Dance
Tomorrow Night
The Bermuda Ball, scheduled
for Saturday, April 19, from 9
until 1 in the gym, is expected
to be a great success, according
to Veteran's Club President Mac
Johnson.
Music will be furnished by the
Debonaires, and there will be an
abundance of favors—both leis
and Bermuda Ball hats.
The
decorations will be in keeping
with the informal atmosphere of
the dance and in general will be
similar to those of last year.
Also featured at this year's
dance will be round tables instead of the conventional rectangular ones. The concessions
will be run by the Vet's Club, and
set-ups will be provided at a
nominal price. The coat check
service will be handled by Alpha
Phi Omega.
" Tickets may be purchased
through Friday for $2.25 from
any member of the Vet's Club,
in the Vet's Club office from 8 to
4 and in Levering Cafeteria and
the dormitory dining hall during
lunch time. Tickets purchased
at the door Saturday night will
cost $2.50.
About 400 couples are expected,
and Johnson emphasized the
importance of a large turnout
since the Vet's Club is considering erecting World War II and
Korean War monuments on campus. The proceeds from this
dance could be used to start a
monument fund.

Out-going President Warren
Wilhide
expressed confidence
that the new Board would have
a successful year. "I think the
Board made good selections for
officers," he commented. Beginning at the next Cotillion Board
meeting the newly - admitted
freshman representatives will
become official Board members,
Wilhide explained.
When asked about his plans
for the coming year, PresidentElect Sauer explained that the
Board is working on the new
BIA-Cotillion Board Calendar,
and that "we will inform all
heads of organizations about
their dates in order to remind
them to start planning early and
avoid having to switch dates."
Commenting on the recent
Student Council move to admit
the Cotillion Board President as
one of its members, Sauer said,
"I feel it is an improvement
for both organizations since 1
have thought for some time all
campus leaders should be admitted to give the Council a
better knowledge of campus
activities. This action will give
the Council more ideas and experience."

Detectives ascertained that the
thief or thieves must have entered the room between 8:1510 p.m. Friday while its occupants were out, Makin explained
that the door and windows of
the room were unlocked but that
the foot locker under his bed
was locked. The thief ripped the
hinge screws out of the wood,
apparently with a screwdriver,
and removed the money, leaving the lock untouched.
"The thief tampered with
nothing else in the room," Makin.
added.
Lynn Rogers, director of the
Hopkins Placement Bureau
which is in charge of student
employment, explained that the
missing money included merchandise costs and salaries for
the student-run
concessions.
Frank Porter and Makin are co.
managers of the concessions,
which employ students to sell
light refreshments at home
athletic events.
"The thief may or may not
have been a student, but whoever it was he was familiar with
the layout," commented Rogers.
Makin explained that he and
his roommate had gone to the
Junior Prom Friday night and
that he did not discover the theft
until early Saturday afternoon
when he opened the locker to deposit money from the Prom.
Makin was chairman of Friday
night's dance.
"The police came immediately
and made a thorough investigation. They took pictures and
made finger-prints," Makin said,
adding that "the money wasn't
my own, but I hope it is recovered."
"It evidently was' a student or
someone extremely familiar with
the layout of dormitory rooms,"
Makin stated.
Police and detectives are making a complete investigation, but
made no reports of any progress
made this week.

Decker Urges IFB
To Induct Prexies
FLASH — Steve Broening of
Beta was elected president and
Pete Doyle of Phi Psi, vicepresident, at yesterday's special
Inter-Fraternity Board election.
A secretary was elected at today's regular IFB meeting.
IFB President Gil Decker presented an annual report to the
Student Council this week in
which he strongly urged that
fraternity presidents be made
members of the Board.
Attacking what he called the
"sometimes poor quality of the
representatives," Decker said,
"often the case is that a fraternity sends a man to the Board
for one of two reasons. It may
not want to give him any other
job and thus appoint him as a
representative to the IFB to get
rid of him. Or it may appoint

an underclassman who is popular
so that he may be in line for a
possible presidency or vice-presidency."
He added, "We never got
around to discussing this problem this year due to the problem of changing the rush rules,
but I would like very much for
next year's IFB to discuss this
as quickly 'as possible."
Break Even
outlined
Decker
the
also
financial position of the Board,
saying it spent some $300 extra
for the fall dance. He added
that the IFB should be able "to
break even if it keeps to our
budget this term."
He testified the IFB has spent
over three months attempting to
modify t h e existing rush
rules. He stated that a committee had first suggested a prom

posal of second-term rushing,
but that this "seemed to meet
with disapproval from everyone."
Now in the works, he said, was
a system which would limit the
rushing period to four weeks. On
the first and the last Saturday,
the fraternities would hold an
open-house. The intermediate
three weeks would be filled by
invitation parties.
Business Matters Only
When asked if he thought this
program might possibly conflict
with the usually scheduled fall
dances, he answered that it
might, but this problem was not
up to the IFB to solve but up to
the sponsoring organizations.
"It's purely a business matter.
These groups know that they
can make more money if they
hold their dances during the
rush period."
Decker also said that the vigilance duty of the IFB had been
"very lax" this year, but added,
"I have had occasion to talk to
Dean Shaffer several times this
year and he has been pleased

Albert D. Hutzler has been appointed chairman of the Cornmitee for New Buildings to be
constructed at the Homewood
campus.
D. Luke Hopkins, chairman of
the Johns Hopkins Fund, which
is handling Hopkins' drive to
raise $76,000,000 in the next ten
years, also announced that
Charles S. Garland will head a
special committee to direct
solicitations from philotherapic
foundations.
Hutzler's Activities
Mr. Hutzler is a 1908 Hopkins
graduate. He has been Chairman of the Board of Hutzler
Brothers company since 1954. He
is a Trustee of the University,
has been an officer of the
Friends of the Library since its
formation in 1931 and has been
active in Baltimore civic affairs

Hopkins Scholar
Receives Grant
Dr. Joseph D. H. Donnay, professor of crystalography and
mineralogy at Johns Hopkins,
has been awarded a Fulbright
Grant to enable him to lecture
at the University of Paris next
year.
A native of Belgium, Dr. Donnay has held his present position at Hopkins since 1946. He
attended the University of Liege.
Belgium, and received his Ph.D.
degree from Stanford University in 1929.
He has written widely on the
fields of crystalography and mineralogy, included a book entitled
Crystal Data.

for many years.
Two buildings at Hopkins are
among the four priority projects
in the $76,000,000 program. They
are a library, estimated to cost
$4,000,000, and a physics building, estimated at $2,500,000. '
Mr. Hutzler said the need for
both buildings is critical. "During the past sixteen years, the
number of books in the library
has more than doubled, and the
library facilities in Gilman Hall,
which were designed to accommodate 200,000 volumes, now
contain 700,000."
Size Factor
Committee
Buildings
The
chairman added that the size of
the physics faculty and the
number of graduate students has
quadrupled since the present
physics building, Rowland Hall,
was built in 1929.
"A dequate facilities are
needed," Mr Hutzler said, "to
house the many new and heavy
types of instruments and machines which are today such a
fundamental part of the study of
physics and nucleonics."

Guidance Association Gets
Gov't. Official For Speech
Applications are now being accepted for the annual spring
meeting of the Maryland Personnel and Guidance Association
to be held on April 26 at The
Johns Hopkins University.
The meeting is open to counselors in elementary and secondary schools, colleges and universities, and to personnel administrators in business, industry, and governmental agencies.
Acting as host for the conference will be the Department of
Education at Johns Hopkins.
About 300 persons are expected
to attend the meetings.
O'Connell To Speak
Highlighting the morning session will be a speech by The
Honorable James T. O'Connell,
Under Secretary of Labor.
In the afternoon the conference attendees will discuss seven
areas of interest: guidance work
in the junior college, counselor certification, job analysis
of the counselor, problems of

seling and their implications for
the practicing counselor.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL. 18, 1958

Parents' Day To Feature
Banquet, Play, Lacrosse
Annual Parents' Day at the
Homewood will be held this year
on Saturday, April 26. The
parents of all Hopkins students
have received invitations to attend, and with the cooperation
of the participating hosts, the
day should prove to he an informative one for all present.
Joe Jeziorski, chairman of the
Student Council committee for
Parents' Day, was quoted as saying that "it certainly isn't too
late for parents to make reservations for Parents' Day. They're
$3.25 per person." Reservations
may be made through Jeziorski
by dropping a note in box_ 1128.
Tour Of Campus
Plans call for the day to begin at Levering Hall at ten
o'clock with a coffee hour and a
short briefing on what else will
be taking place, where, and
when. At 10:30 ODK will take
over by conducting a number of
Parents through the labs, buildings, classes and various other

Orientation
Anyone interested in serving on Orientation Week committees should turn in their
name, class, previous experience, major and box number to Charles Ginsberg, Box
2024. The deadline is Tuesday, April 22.

interesting spots on campus. At
approximately 11:30 everyone
will again meet, this time at
Shriver Hall, where Dr. Clarence
Long will address the group on
the topic of the Hopkins role in
education from the viewpoint of
a professor in a certain field.
The group will then disband to
eat lunch, parents and students
to secure their own. A section
will be reserved in the stands
for all guests for the HopkinsLoyola lacrosse game.
Banquet Follows Lacrosse
The evening's program will
commence at 6:30 with a
banquet at Levering Hall. Professor Thomas Hubbard will be
the master of ceremonies; Dean
Schaffer will give the main
speech, the keynote again being
education. Following the banquet, the "Y" will play host with
a program and awards. A number of the faculty -will be at the
tables with the parents.
This is as far as the present
plans go, but the parents may
want to attend the Barnstormer's production of "Charlie's
Aunt." A number of fraternities
are considering holding open
house for the parents of their
members.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 18, 1958

Dr. Fagin, Soon To Leave,
Speaks On O'Neill Critics
By PAUL BERMAN
This year's final Amos Taylor,
Jr. Memorial Lecture was delivered last Sunday evening in the
balcony foyer of Shriver Hall.
The lecturer, Dr. N. Bryllion
Fagin, retired professor of drama
and English at this university.
chose for his topic, "Eugene
O'Neill and his Critics." As with
his forthcoming book on this
topic, Dr. Fagin's lecture concerned itself with the career of
New London, Connecticut born
playwright Eugene O'Neill, and
his critics.
In his opening remarks, Dr.
Fagin acknowledged the fact
that he was dealing with a very
controversial figure in the person of O'Neill. Eugene O'Neill's
plays have been reviewed and
criticized in many parts of the
world. They have been performed
in Germany, Japan and Sweden.
Playgoers in the latter country
have been particularly receptive
to the works of O'Neill. His
somewhat autobiographical play,
"Long Day's Journey into Night,"
received its world premiere by
the Royal Swedish Theatre in
1956.
Consistent with human nature,
the more honors O'Neill received
for his playwrighting, the more
unfavorable his critics became.
When he received the Nobel
Prize in 1936, criticism was at
its height.
Expelled Princetonian
Eugene O'Neill was a modest
man who began his literary career as a poet. Although O'Neill
had attended the best schools

At a meeting last Monday night in the dormitory
recreation room, the scene may have been 'set for a great
revelation in dormitory living. The newly selected faculty
advisors met with the Dean and the DSRC to discuss
dormitory problems. And there were many. However,
something may be done this time. With progressive
leadership from the new DSRC,constructive guidance from
the new advisors, and cooperation from the Dean, the
Alumni Memorial Residences may just come close tv
becoming that "home away from home" that we read
about so much in the collegiate catalogs.
Plans have been proposed to renovate the lounges, dim
the noise, help the freshman adjust to the difficult problem of dormitory living. But, the most important aim of
the men present, and the one* most discussed, and the one
most paramount, is the development of house unity and
spirit, the development of autonomous houses which can
function alone, replete with self-government.
The fact is that the dormitories have grown too large
to be governed effectively by just one body of sixteen men.
An attempt was made to extend this government with the
addition of floor representatives. However, this plan can
never accomplish so great a task as that set before it.
Each house must organize within itself. Each must
have its own officers, its own athletic teams, its own individuality if one is expected to find a place where he can
identify himself.

In 1914, it was discovered that

in a New London, Connecticut,

thoughts into several small oneact playlets about the sea. Upon
his release, O'Neill took several
of his manuscripts to a little
theatre group, "The Provincetown Players." This group produced these playlets with great
success. Eventually, "Provincetown Players" presented O'Neill's
first full-length play, Beyond
the Horizon, on Broadway in
1921. This play received rave reviews and was followed in succeeding years by The Emperor
Jones and The Hairy Ape.
O'Neill discarded proven playwrighting formulae and adopted

Correspondence

A Prior Restraint
The Student Council, by voting to include a representative of this paper in its membership, has attempted,
regardless of the good intention of some of its representatives, to pull a cutie known as 'ham stringing'. It has
turned a deaf ear upon our written and verbal arguments
against membership, and thus, we feel, committed an open
flagrancy known in law circles as 'prior restraint': knowing that this column has often criticized the actions of
the Council, and realizing that this column might be
hesitant to do so if it is included in Council membership,
the Council enacted legislation countering our action prior
to the enactment of any such action.
A referendum is in the offing. Our arguments are
in the news story on page 1. We ask that the undergraduates vote wisely on that referendum.
We trust that if we become a Student Council member
our successors, regardless of popular sentiment regarding
the reasoning behind a blast, will continue to criticize the
Council if they feel justified to do so. However, we editors
would not like to put them on the spot, and therefore ask
that the referendum not be passed.
What will happen if our successors refuse to attend
meetings? The Student Council has the power to dissolve
the News-Letter, we were informed. That we'd like to see.

THE POSTMAN COMETH
I

have recently received several letters from readers which
have been so interesting, so piquant, so je ne sais quoi, that I
feel I must share them with all of you. The letters and my
replies follow:
SIR:
Maybe you can help me. I came up to college eight years
ago. On my very first day I got into a bridge game in the
student union. I am still in the same bridge game. I have never
gone to class, cracked a book, or paid any tuition. All I do
is play bridge.
To explain my long absence and keep the money coining
from home, I told a harmless little lie; I said I was in medical
school. This made Dad (my father) terribly proud. It also
enabled me to keep playing bridge. We were both very happy.
But all good things must come to an end. Mine ended when
I came home for Christmas vacation. I arrived to find that
Sister (my sister) was in the hospital with an ingrown spleen.
Dr. Norbert Sigafoos, the eminent ingrown spleen surgeon, was
scheduled to operate, but unfortunately he was run over by
a hot-food cart on the way to the scrubbing room.

(Continued from Page 6)
the life of the students in the
dormitories.
In this time and in this country, in a city that has received
praise for its courage in simply
allowing children with two types
of skin pigmentation to attend
school together, the fact remains
that Hopkins is truly an island
of freedom and, equality in a
wide, tragic sea; and that we are
still isolated, still sealed off from
the people of this city.
John M. Brewer
To the Editors:
When I first came to Hopkins
over three years ago I was'forced
by social pressure to learn an
interminable card game called
Pinochle. As if this weren't
enough, I now have been forced
to learn a new, equally interminable and even more frustrating game called bridge. I have
been forced to sit through hours
of .pure misery, enduring the
silent scorn that only superior
bridge-players can bestow upon
the neophyte.
However, the purpose behind
this letter is not to complain of
the lack of sympathy accorded
my mistakes. I have noticed
the sudden superabundance of
bridge games extending until
very late in the evening or early
in the morning. When these
take place in the Snack Bar,

I have noticed that Mary is often
prevented from being able to
close up as early as she would
like. Then too, the noise and
rather foul language must greatly try her patience.
While it is too much to be
expected that the bridge games
will cease or at least be confined
to more reasonable hours of the
evening, I would like to suggest
that the DSRC use some of the
vast amount of space available
in the basement to set up a card
room. A few tables and solidlyconstructed chairs could be provided, good lighting installed,
and a deep pit sunk in the floor
for cigarette butts, candy wrappers, and unsuccessful players
who go down, doubled and vulnerable, on one bids.
I suggest this instead of the
dormitory lounges, which are
poorly lighted and cannot generally furnish a sufficiency of
chairs for the players.
I might add, also, that the
late, late shift of cardsmen invariably manages to completely
litter the area which they

Even in the absence of any

Dear Harlow:
Indeed I do have the solution for you—the
solution that has never failed me when things
close in: Light up a Marlboro! Knots untie as
you puff that fine rich tobacco. Shade becomes
light as that grand flavor comes freely and friendlily through that splendid filter. Who can stay
glum when Marlboro gives you such a lot to like?
.Not I. Not you. Not nobody.
SIR:
Just off the campus where I go to school there is a lake
called Lake Widgiwagan. Thirty years ago when my father was
an undergraduate here he went fishing one day in Lake Widgiwagan and dropped his Deke pin in the water. He dived for
days but never found it.
Just yesterday—thirty years later, mark you!—I went fishing in Widgiwagan. I caught a four-pound bass. I took the
fish home, cut it open, and what do you think I found inside?

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 18, 1958

Hopkins Netm e n
To Volley Hens
On Home Courts

By STAN HANDMAKER
Sports Editor
Wins by the varsity baseball, lacrosse, and tennis
teams last week give the Hopkins spring sports perspective
a bright outlook for this year.
The baseball team gained an upset victory over Loyola,
7-2, at the Greyhounds' home field last Tuesday. The netinen also pulled an upset, downing the Randolph-Macon
Yellow Jackets, 5-3, last Saturday at Ashland, Virginia,
While the stickmen won as expected, 16-7, over Princeton
at the Tigers' home .grounds.
Following the Jays' win on the diamond over Harvard,
Paul Menton, sports editor of the Baltimore Sun, mentioned
the game in a list under the title "The Impossible Can
Happen" We would like to call to Mr. Menton's attention
'Hopkins' win over Loyola, demonstrating that the "impossible" can happen more than once with the same team.
As to the tennis squad's league victory over RandolphMacon, we are glad to see that the "minor" sports are
.iving more-than-minor performances. Hopkins is cur12e.ntly in first- place in the northern league of the Mason'Dixon conference.
The lacrosse team is expected to continue its winning
Ways, meeting Washington and Lee this Saturday at 2:30
Pan. on Homewood Field. The Generals' goalie, who gave
Lhe best performance against the Blue Jays last year,
,
tu,eing credited with twenty-nine saves, poses the greatest
threat. However, Hopkins still has what we consider the
attack to compensate for Lewis's or any other goalie's
capability in the nets.
Although we realize that the Jays have to play each
gaine as it comes, we are looking to the last three games,
(Navy, Maryland, and Mt. Washington) for Hopkins to
show its true colors.
The big. question these days is "If Army and Hopkins
('0th finish their seasons undefeated, who wins the chamPionship ?"
Ross Smith, president of the United' States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, stated in the Sun that the
,championship will not be decided on strict points and that
both schedules will have to be evaluated.

Johns Hopkins varsity tennis
squad, victorious in its match at
Randolph-Macon last Tuesday,
will face Delaware next Tuesday
at 3:00 p.m. on home courts, and
on Wednesday will travel to
Towson Teachers for a match.

Randolph-Macon's Yellow Jackets, Co-Captain Don Squair was

victory from Emerson, and Bob
Spielman was taking Thienprasiddh 4-6, 8-6, 6-1.
The rest of the matches went
to the Jays in straight sets, with
Carl Steeg taking a 6-0, 6-1 victory over Dillingham, Mike Garrick topping Lambert 6-3, 7-5,
and Stu Viess downing Nelson
6-2, 7-5.
In the doubles matches, the
Blue Jay combination of Squair
and Hubbard was downed by the
Yellow Jackets' Adams and Lambert 7-9, 8-6, 4-6; Spielman and
Garrick tied Emerson and Thienprasiddh 0-6, 6-2, 13-13; and
Art Brittingham and Marshall
Goldman lost to Johnson and
Dillingham 3-6, 3-6.
